title: Untitled
text: For a generation of glass artists working in mid-twentieth century Czechoslovakia, the relative unimportance given to applied arts by the restrictions of the Eastern bloc allowed for the development of a highly abstracted and conceptual movement in glasswork. In the 1960s, after completing his training at the famous Czech glassmaking schools in Nový Bor and 'elezný Brod, Vízner began his work as part of this generation. Many of his pieces focus on the tension between the utilitarian and the artistic object. Untitled is an example of his lasting preoccupation with this concept. The basic form underlying the sculpture is the ordinary and stereotypically functional plate; however, distended, curving shapes render the basic form unusable. Vízner is also known for his intensity of color, which absorbs the viewer's attention and masks lines and surfaces of his forms.
description: dark blue glass disk; rounded bottom; slightly concave top with raised line at center with polished concave surface
creditline: Gift of Daniel Greenberg and Susan Steinhauser
